# 1970-1990

## 6a. Focusing only on the time period from 1970 to 1990, regress log sales on log prices to estimate the price elasticity of demand over that period. Interpret your results.

```{r} 
#| echo: false
#| label: model.a

install.packages("broom", repos = "https://cloud.r-project.org/")
library(broom)

# format output as a table
model.a.results <- tidy(model.a, conf.int = TRUE)

# display results in a table
knitr::kable(model.a.results, digits = 3, caption = "Regression Results: Log Sales on Log Price")

```


\newpage 

## 7a. Regress log sales on log prices using the total (federal and state) cigarette tax (in dollars) as an instrument for log prices. Interpret your results and compare your estimates to those without an instrument. Are they different? If so, why?

```{r} 
#| echo: false
#| label: ivs.a

# format output as a table
ivs.a.results <- tidy(ivs.a, conf.int = TRUE)

# display results in a table
knitr::kable(model.a.results, digits = 3, caption = "Regression Results: Log Sales on Log Price Using Total Cigarette Price")
```


\newpage 

## 8a. Show the first stage and reduced-form results from the instrument.

```{r} 
#| echo: false
#| label: first.stage & reduced.form a

# convert models to tidy data frames
first.stage.results.a <- tidy(first.stage.a, conf.int = TRUE)
reduced.form.results.a <- tidy(reduced.form.a, conf.int = TRUE)

# format tables
first.stage.results.a %>%
  kable(digits = 3, caption = "First Stage Regression: Effect of Log Total Tax on Log Price") %>%
  kable_styling()

reduced.form.results.a %>%
  kable(digits = 3, caption = "Reduced Form Regression: Effect of Log Total Tax on Log Sales") %>%
  kable_styling()
```
